The Exchange was designed by the John Graham Company to house the Seattle Stock Exchange. Today, this iconic building has been modernized to support some of the most innovative companies. BUILDING UPGRADE: Circa 2015 the building underwent a comprehensive seismic upgrade. The upgrade was designed for the 225 year (20% exceedance in 50 years) earthquake. This is equivalent to a BSE-1E hazard level for existing building as defined in ASCE-41-13. The work included adding six full height shear walls on the inside of exterior walls to the 19th floor. Nine other shear walls were added. Seven of these were for the 19th floor to the roof, accommodating the vertical setbacks. The new shear panels were reinforced concrete, applied as shotcrete. The new reinforcing was doweled to the existing concrete columns and beams. Selected areas of the floor were upgraded, presumably to increase the capacity of the horizontal diaphragms. Selected beams also were retrofitted.   SUBMISSION DOCUMENTS: Attached are the following documents to assist your underwriting review: Statement of Insurable Values Workbook 6-Year Loss History Engineering Report Below is a summary of the Key Policy Terms we are seeking for the upcoming renewal: KEY PROGRAM LIMITS: KEY PROGRAM DEDUCTIBLES: QUOTE DUE DATE: Tuesday, July 8th   We will be in touch soon to discuss – in the meantime, please let us know if any questions or additional information needed. Content:
Asked Tom who is handling the casualty. Asked Stephanie if she even wanted to support writing the property this year. Needed Information/Notepad: AIRE Initial Review Some property thoughts are below. I know Adam is looking at the other lines, and I’m happy to loop in Mike Spence if you need anything else on that (a number of the properties appear to have swimming pools, etc.), I just figured I would take care of what I can… I was able to find flood reviews in ArcNet for 4 of the locations, and I looked up the other 2 myself. Brief notes are in the attached modified SOV. In short, we are certainly looking at a flood exposure at the Lincolnshire Marriott (10 Marriott Drive, Lincolnshire, IL) – the flood zone skirts the exterior part of this building, and ArcOps developed flood LE’s of $1,022,906 for the 100-yr event and $1,719,129 for the 500-yr event. The other potential flood exposure is in Northbrook, IL (933 Skokie Blvd). Per ArcOps review, FEMA maps indicate there is no flood exposure here, but CATLAS identifies a flood exposure, so ArcOps developed flood LE’s of $1,788,889 for the 100-yr event and $2,666,666 for the 500-yr event. I have a message out to our team, and plan to discuss this further with Steve Hanly or another flood specialist, because it’s not the first time I’ve run into a situation where FEMA says we’re safe by multiple feet but CATLAS says we’re underwater. I’m not sure if you have a standard approach to this, but it also doesn’t help that my CATLAS isn’t working right now, so I’m not able to perform that analysis myself. There does appear to be a basement, so that could be impacting the LE. I will get back to you ASAP on this exposure, but for now let’s assume that the current LE’s listed above (~$1.7 M and $2.6 M) are correct. With regards to a servicing plan for this account, the only potential pre-bind survey would be to the Lincolnshire location (10 Marriott Drive, Lincolnshire, IL), mainly to validate sprinkler coverage. We could also potentially take care of this with an email, but either way, I’m looking at some photos online of that property, and I don’t see sprinklers in a number of the photos. It’s possible that they are outdated, or that the photos have been edited to remove sprinklers (a surprisingly common occurrence), but I’m seeing enough photos without sprinklers that I want to validate the reported “100% sprinklered” from the SOV. Post-bind, I think the “Light Hazard” survey ordering guidelines would be appropriate: I’ll get back to you ASAP regarding flood exposure in Northbrook, IL, but if you need anything else in the meantime, please let me know. Company: Price it
Content: I’d ask that you review this to see what you think is missing, out or order, excessive etc.  We can have a quick chat over it collectively soon to formalize one list for new and one for renewal. We can also clean up the format a bit.   Refresh about the insured   What do they do?   Is it still in our appetite  Check ARC MES has helpful descriptions of the operations for the building   Do they have any losses and what?   Loss ratio  Check UW rationale  Previous UW notes, any notes about this renewal approach, important info typically in here. REF is also good to check as an overvide   Check D&B financials  Fin stress should be above 30 or else REF   Get updated SOV   Send to Uts   Make sure numbers/COPE/etc is matching with SOV etc!!!  Check occupancy codes in CUBE   Run PCPEU pricing to see where we need to be   Check middle market registry   Check ITV  ( to broker "I have to get full value" )  Use CoreLogic to run separate if needed   Check ARC/ do we need to schedule a visit? Ideally 90days advance review  CAT check  What is the AAL and GPW to AAL ratio  Flood zones?  Severe storm zone 1 or 2?  Tier 1 or 2?  Check authority grid for guidance as well   Referral?   Any specifics that will need to be referred early to Klep etc  Authority grid  If SAF will need to do REF early   Talk with steve on rate increase per PCPEU   Do I need reinsurance? Boiler?   Boiler don’t include stock  Request quote   Communicate with broker on rate increase  They want all in premium increase, take that into account   Price it  Check to see if TRIA was bought prior year  If not, uncheck TRIA then rate it then add back when you send quote   Send to broker  Bind it   Never click "finalize binder doc"   Click bind policy in orange Don’t forget before quote   Check to make sure values in coverages match   Make sure eRe quote is priced at right value   Make sure you have the right forms  Add TRIA if not already NB checklist   What does the insured do?   Why are they on the market?   What is their wanted rate/premium/deductible?  Is it in our appetite? Occupancy/SIC?  Check cube for previous submissions   Location of account?   Check COPE   Ask for previous loss reports of 5 years   Ask for previous engineering reports   Run D & B   Do I need reinsurance? Boiler?   Check CAT and run risk modeling   Flood limit/ded   Severe storm (major damage states-AR,CO,KS,LA,MO,NE,OK,TX)   Terrorism?   Referrals?   Run ITV  Do we need to schedule ARC? Types of info you may need from broker (depending on some accounts):  BI worksheet  Rent rolls  Valuation report of building  Previous engineering reports  Previous loss reports from old carriers  Equipment schedules

They have a system that prevents losses in machines. Pressure drop right before a spark and an explosion. This system activates and extinguishes any fire hazard. Industry Group: Food Manufacturing They do Chocolate. Some dairy products, Milk Chocolate, they buy the chocolate in bulk and melt it onto pretzels. They only thing they make is gummy bears. They will roast nuts and cover those in chocolate. Named Insured schedule: Action Items: Why are you marketing the account? They ended up on a layered program AXA takes the first layer With 7 layers above to the total TIV Expiring Carrier? AXA Takes the first layer Who am I competing against? AXA, Travelers is looking at it this year. AFM has looked at it, AFM did a report and inspection which took two days. AFM did not release their report. Marsh engineering is going to go out and share that report. Do you have any current loss control reports such as rec letters, sprinkler adequacy reports, etc. That you can share? No, There are five buildings all built into one plant, no second plant. So there is some fire walls and protections put in to prevent a total loss. Doubts that the insured will install in-rack sprinklers. They will just reprogram their pallets to provide ample space. Main core in the HVAC system they have a kill switch which will stop airflow and smoke from spreading. They have a shed with a kill switch for the HVAC What are the issues that can drive the account to move? Looking to move back to a guaranteed cost program. Last year was the first year they have not been able to get a guaranteed cost program put together. Mitsui was on it for the loss and exited the market (left America for non-reverse flow accounts). Sompo had it for two years. Berkley wrote it for one year but then lost their fac on the property. Berkley still has the casualty. Sompo did not want it back based on the high density rack storage issue. GL and Auto is with Berkley. WC is on a loss sensitive program with a captive. Umbrella - Berkley 2-5 and excess of $15M How is your submission different from the expiring program? When do you need this by? Owner never sleeps. Early October. If I meet your expectations will you move it? Where are the other products and can I compete on them as well? Requested Commission: 15% Requested Payment Plan: Nothing, Pre-pay it annual.
